description: From Middle English quayer, from Anglo-Norman quaier and Old French quaer, from Vulgar Latin *quaternus, from Latin quaterni (“four at a time”), from quater (“four times”). Doublet of cahier.

entries.meaning: One-twentieth of a ream of paper; a collection of twenty-four or twenty-five sheets of paper of the same size and quality, unfolded or having a single fold.
examples: Under the year 1533 we are told that the ream contained twenty quires.

entries.meaning: (bookbinding) A set of leaves which are stitched together, originally a set of four pieces of paper (eight leaves, sixteen pages). This is most often a single signature (i.e. group of four), but may be several nested signatures.

verbs.description: quire (third-person singular simple present quires, present participle quiring, simple past and past participle quired)

entries.meaning: (bookbinding) To prepare quires by stitching together leaves of paper.
examples: Now, in the first folio volume of 1616, the paging, signatures, and quiring are continuous and regular throughout.
Yea, and the prophet of the heav'nly lyre, / Great Solomon sings in the English quire  […]

entries.meaning: One quarter of a cruciform church, or the architectural area of a church used by the choir, often near the apse.

verbs.description: quire (third-person singular simple present quires, present participle quiring, simple past and past participle quired)

examples: I saw the 'potamus take wing / Ascending from the damp savannas, / And quiring angels round him sing / The praise of God, in loud hosannas.
